sub_subject.name: Hermeneutics (The Art of Interpretation)
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Hermeneutics (The Art of Interpretation) (Bible & Theology)

objectives.objective_text: Identify that the Bible tells one big true story.
Name the Bible as the best helper to understand the Bible.
Identify that God used men to write the Bible.
Name the person who wrote the book (like Luke).
Identify a story vs. a song.
Name a letter (Epistle) vs. a rule (Law).
Identify that God told us more and more over time.
Name Jesus as the final word from God.
Identify that the Bible tells us true things that really happened.
Name the writer (like Moses or Paul) of a book.
Identify what happened right before a story.
Name the book that a verse comes from.
Observe that stories have a beginning, middle, and end.
Recall that God never contradicts Himself.
Observe that the New Testament helps us understand the Old Testament.
Recall that the writer wanted to tell us something specific.
Recall that the Bible has different kinds of writing.
Observe that poetry uses picture words.
Recall that Adam knew a little, but we know a lot.
Observe how the story grows like a tree.
Recall that words have specific meanings.
Observe that we read the Bible just like we read other true stories.
Recall that we shouldn't pick verses like magic tricks.
Summarize the rule: 'Scripture interprets Scripture'.
Explain that clear verses help us understand hard verses.
Explain the unity of the Bible.
Defend the internal consistency of the Scriptures.
Produce a study reconciling difficult parallel passages (e.g., Kings/Chronicles or Gospels).
Ask 'What did the writer want us to know?'
Summarize the main point the author was making.
Explain that we can't make the Bible mean whatever we want.
Explain the concept of 'Dual Authorship' (Holy Spirit and Man).
Defend the objective meaning of Scripture.
Summarize the difference between History (Kings) and Prophecy (Isaiah).
Explain that a Parable is a made-up story to teach a truth.
Categorize Bible books by their genre.
Explain why Wisdom Literature (Proverbs) are probabilities, not promises.
Defend the historicity of Narrative against 'myth' interpretations.
Summarize the growth from the Garden to the City.
Explain that the Old Testament is the shadow, and Jesus is the substance.
Explain why we don't follow ceremonial laws anymore.
Defend the superiority of the New Covenant revelation (Hebrews 1).
Summarize the 'plain meaning' of the text.
Explain that we must understand what it meant to the first readers.
Explain why we avoid allegorizing historical narratives.
Perform research on the cultural background of a passage to illuminate meaning.
Summarize the paragraph surrounding a verse.
Explain that taking things 'out of context' changes the meaning.
Explain the three circles of context: Immediate, Book, and Canonical.
Defend the principle that context determines meaning.
Produce an exegetical outline tracing the author's thought process.
Identify the beginning, middle, and end of a story.
Compare two verses on the same topic to get the full picture.
Apply cross-references to find other verses.
Analyze apparent contradictions (e.g., Paul vs. James) using harmonization.
Connect OT types to NT antitypes.
Compare what I *feel* about a verse with what the author *said*.
Apply the idea that there is one meaning but many applications.
Analyze the 'Occasion' for writing (Why did Paul write Galatians?).
Interpret the difference between Authorial Intent and Reader Response.
Connect the human author's intent to the Divine Author's intent.
Compare reading a Psalm with reading a Commandment.
Analyze the rules for interpreting Apocalyptic literature (Daniel/Revelation).
Interpret Hebrew Poetry (recognizing parallelism, not literalism).
Connect the genre to the author's purpose.
Compare the partial knowledge of Moses with the full knowledge in Christ.
Apply the blessing of having the whole Bible.
Analyze the unfolding of the Covenant (Seed -> Land -> King -> World).
Interpret the 'Mystery' that was hidden but is now revealed (Ephesians 3).
Connect the Levitical sacrifices to the finality of the Cross.
Compare a literal reading with a made-up meaning.
Apply the rule: 'If the plain sense makes sense, seek no other sense.'
Analyze the historical setting of a book (author, date, audience).
Interpret the text according to the rules of grammar.
Connect the meaning of a passage to the history of that time.
Compare the Immediate Context (surrounding verses) with the Broad Context (whole book).
Apply context to correct a wrong idea (e.g., 'I can do all things' in Phil 4).
Analyze the logical flow of an argument in an epistle.
Interpret a difficult verse by looking at the whole chapter.
Connect a single passage to the overall theme of the book.
Identify what God wants me to do today.
Name a way to obey the verse.
Name the main idea.
Identify that the Bible was written by hand a long time ago.
Name the Scribes who copied it carefully.
Identify what a story teaches about God.
Name Jesus in the story.
Identify big words in the Bible (Grace, Sin, Faith).
Name a Bible dictionary as a helper.
Evaluate how the Apostles interpreted the OT (hermeneutics of the Apostles).
Evaluate postmodern views that 'the author is dead'.
Evaluate the difference between Descriptive (Narrative) and Prescriptive (Didactic) texts.
Evaluate Dispensational vs. Covenantal views of progression.
Evaluate the dangers of 'Reader-Response' theory.
Evaluate popular misinterpretations based on isolation of verses.
Recall that the Bible is for us, even though it's old.
Recall that stories have a shape.
Observe repeated words.
Recall that we can trust the Bible we have.
Observe the footnotes in a Bible.
Recall that all stories point to one big Truth.
Observe how God acts the same way in different stories.
Recall that words mean special things.
Observe that the same word can be used in different places.
Construct a thesis on the intent of a specific book.
Synthesize the human personality of the author with the doctrine of Inspiration.
Construct a hermeneutic for Epistolary literature (occasional nature).
Synthesize genre analysis into the study of a specific book.
Construct a timeline of theological development.
Synthesize the organic unity of the Bible from seed to fruit.
Construct a defense of the Grammatical-Historical hermeneutic.
Construct a context chart for a specific book.
Ask 'How can I be like Jesus?'
Summarize the difference between 'Then' (Bible times) and 'Now'.
Explain that we must understand it before we apply it.
Explain the danger of legalistic application.
Defend the relevance of the Old Testament for modern living.
Produce a devotional or sermon outline applying a text to a specific audience.
Summarize the outline of a chapter.
Explain how paragraphs group ideas together.
Explain the 'Inclusio' (bookends) technique.
Defend an interpretation based on the grammatical structure.
Summarize how we got our English Bible from Hebrew and Greek.
Explain that sometimes copiers made tiny spelling mistakes.
Explain the reliability of the transmission process.
Summarize the doctrine taught in a passage.
Explain how a verse fits with the rest of the Bible.
Categorize a passage under a doctrine (e.g., God, Man, Sin).
Explain the 'Analogy of Faith'.
Defend a doctrine using proof texts correctly handled.
Summarize the definition of key terms like 'Justification'.
Explain that the Bible was written in Hebrew and Greek.
Explain the danger of the 'Root Fallacy' (etymology is not meaning).
Produce a study on a concept (like 'Flesh' in Paul) using a lexicon.
Compare a cultural custom (sandals) with the principle (humility).
Apply a specific application to school or family.
Analyze the 'Principlizing Bridge' (finding the timeless truth).
Interpret commands that are cultural vs. universal.
Connect the Indicative (Who you are) to the Imperative (What you do).
Compare the structure of a Poem (lines) with a Letter (paragraphs).
Apply identifying the 'Big Idea'.
Analyze Chiasm (A-B-C-B-A structure) in poetry.
Interpret the logical flow words (Therefore, But, For).
Connect the structure of a book to its message.
Compare the number of Bible copies with other old books (like Homer).
Apply confidence in the Word of God.
Analyze why some Bibles have brackets around verses (e.g., Mark 16).
Interpret the difference between a 'variant' and an 'error'.
Connect the Dead Sea Scrolls to the accuracy of the OT.
Perform simple comparisons of translation philosophies (KJV vs. ESV vs. NIV).
Compare a specific command with a general principle.
Analyze the theological implications of a text.
Interpret a narrative text to find the theological principle.
Compare how a word is used in different verses.
Apply a Strong's Concordance number to find a definition.
Analyze the 'Semantic Range' of a word (it can mean different things).
Interpret a word based on how the specific author uses it.
Connect a Greek word (like Agape) to its definition.
Synthesize the relationship between history and theology.
Defend the importance of precise definitions in theology.
Evaluate modern ethical dilemmas using biblical principles.
Evaluate the macro-structure of a book (e.g., Matthew's 5 discourses).
Evaluate the impact of textual variants on doctrine (none affected).
Evaluate a systematic doctrine based on biblical evidence.
Evaluate the usage of a word in the Septuagint (LXX) vs. NT.
Interpret obscure passages in light of systematic theology.
Construct a culturally relevant application of an ancient text.
Construct a sentence diagram of a complex Pauline sentence.
Construct a defense of the text based on the vast number of manuscripts.
Synthesize the history of the textus receptus vs. critical text.
Construct a theological statement based on exegetical work.
Synthesize the results of word studies, grammar, and history into a doctrinal conclusion.
Construct a word study on a key theological term.
Synthesize the syntax and the theology of a passage.
Construct a systematic theology on a topic using the whole Bible.
Connect Exegesis (the text) to Systematic Theology (the doctrine).
